did.langmaterial: Most of the material is in English some in Russian, Armenian, Polish, Turkish and Arabic
did.abstract: The collection contains materials related to Jane Otteson King's participation as a clarinetist in the University of Michigan's Symphony Band Tour of the Soviet Union, Near East and Eastern Europe in 1961.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.
No further additions to the paperss are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Jane Otteson King papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Jane Otteson King is a 1964 University of Michigan alumnus from Dowagiac, Michigan. She was a clarinet player with the Symphony Band during the band's 1961 tour of the Soviet Union, Near East, and Eastern Europe. William D. Revelli and George Cavender directed the band during the 15 week cultural tour which was sponsored by the United States State Department.
In the summer of 2011 she was also part of a group of alumni that accompanied the current University of Michigan Symphony on a tour through China.

scopecontent.p: The Jane Otteson King papers (1 linear foot) are comprised of materials related to the 1961 University of Michigan Symphony Band tour through the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and the Near East. The 15 week tour occurred during the cold war and was sponsored by the United States Department of State.

The Band Tour Papers series contains materials produced and collected by King during the 1961 Michigan Band Tour. It includes personal correspondence, a journal, invitations received by the band, several books acquired during the trip, postcards, photo souvenirs, travel guides and materials, news clippings, press releases, concert programs and some published material. Additionally, tour materials include itineraries, travel preparation documents and telegrams. The journal provides a detailed daily account of the tour from their parting date in February 19, 1961 until May 29, 1961. The correspondence folder contains letters sent home, received, and a few telegrams and postcards. Among the miscellaneous items are a Leningrad circus ticket, a ticket to the Swan Lake ballet, Postcards of Yuri Gagarin and actor Genadii Yudin, pins given by audiences to band members and a khaffiyeh holder. The subseries are arranged in alphabetical order.

The Visual Materials series includes photographic prints of the trip, three posters, and close to 360 color slides. Among the photographs there are small souvenir picture packets of Kiev, Yerevan and Moscow. Also, there are prints of the University of Michigan News and Information service photos as well as personal ones of the places they visited, the people, general sightseeing, and members of the group.

The slides are organized following Otteson's original slide box arrangement by place visited and number. The headings used include Moscow, Leningrad, Minsk, Kiev, Odessa, Sukhumi, Kharkov, Tbilisi, Yerevan, Baku, Cairo, Amman, Jerusalem, Petra, Beirut, Cyprus, Istanbul, Athens, Rumania, and Poland. These feature general sightseeing, leisure time of members of the group, and some candid shots. A few slides are not identified but can be found in the last slide folder.

did.unittitle: Posters (oversize, located at UBI mul F90)
